item.title: Reticulate
item.description: #R-stuido hw<-"Hello World!" hw ## [1] "Hello World!" #python print("Hello World!") ## Hello World! Before even diving into reticulate, it is obvious that R-studio and Python have their differences. It was a difficult transition, but I have come to really enjoy Python. Reticulate allows you to work between R and Python, and an example will be shown below. library(reticulate) library(ggplot2) library(tidyverse) ## ── Attaching packages ─────────────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse 1.3.0 ── ## ✓ tibble 3.

item.title: Darrell the Dachshund
item.description: All about Darrell Hello world! Here is my dacshund, Darrell, in a cow costume.Darrell is six years old and his favorite things to do include playing fetch, going through the Starbucks drive-thru for puppuccinos, and sleeping inside of the fuzziest blankets he can find. I got Darrell when he was just nine months old, he was dumped in a parking lot and of course I had to take him home with me.

item.title: Project 2: Modeling
item.description: library(dplyr) ## ## Attaching package: 'dplyr' ## The following objects are masked from 'package:stats': ## ## filter, lag ## The following objects are masked from 'package:base': ## ## intersect, setdiff, setequal, union library(readxl) collegedat<-read_excel("CollegeDistance.xls") ## New names: ## * `` -> ...1 head(collegedat) ## # A tibble: 6 x 15 ## ...1 gender ethnicity score fcollege mcollege home urban unemp wage ## <dbl> <chr> <chr> <dbl> <chr> <chr> <chr> <chr> <dbl> <dbl> ## 1 1 male other 39.

item.title: project1
item.description: library(ggplot2) library(tidyverse) library(readr) drinks <- read_csv("drinks.csv") library(readxl) GDP1 <- read_excel("GDP1.xls") library(readxl) population_figures_by_country_csv_csv <- read_excel("population-figures-by-country-csv_csv.xls") Introduction: I have chosen three datasets to merge for this project. I chose to merge three datasets due to the fact that I could not find a sufficient amount of data by only merging two datasets. The first dataset I chose displays the servings of beer, wine and spirits in average serving sizes per person by country in 2010.
